name: Teaching Guide: Exploring Women of the Antebellum Reform Movement

affiliation.name: Scott County High School, Georgetown, Kentucky

hasPart.name: Questions
hasPart.text:
1. Using information in the [letter from the superintendent](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1071), explain how Dorothea Dix helped the lives of those suffering from mental illnesses.
2. How does Emma Willard describe her plan in her [address](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1072)?
3. What issues are raised by Susan B. Anthony in her [letter to Elizabeth Cady Stanton](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1074)?
4. Using Emma Willard’s [address](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1072), Catherine Beecher’s [*Treatise*](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1075), and the [catalog from Mount Holyoke](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1076), create a chart comparing various plans for women’s education and various benefits outlined. Who called for more change? 
5. In her [letter](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1078), what reasons does Prudence Crandall provide for switching her school to education of African American girls? Why is it important that she is writing to William Lloyd Garrison?
6. Using the [letter from Anne Weston Warren](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1079) and the [letter from Angelina Grimke](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1080), explain ways in which women participated in the Abolitionist movement. 
7. What is the significance of Garrison’s praise for Maria W. Stewart in the [excerpt from her *Meditations*](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/1081)? What accomplishments of Stewart’s are highlighted in the letter and how would they have challenged the racial and gender roles of the time period?

hasPart.name: Activity
hasPart.text: Using the documents in the set as a beginning, ask students to research one of the women leaders from this time period. Each student should prepare a presentation including a poster fighting for the cause of their reforming figure, a Facebook page for the individual, and a storyboard and script for a ten-minute documentary about her life. If there is time, ask students use their research to create a digital documentary.
